I'm perfectly happy for things to change again if the dev list discussion reaches a new conclusion for [BEAM-38](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-38).
Updated the commit message; The RunnableOnService tests all pass, but a future-change that replaces the DirectRunner in its entirety does not, due to the implementation of `Write`

Also, Amit, if you could take a look at the build logs or know why Aggregators constructed a Pipeline Construction time wouldn't show up? These are effectively identical to the PAssert aggregators but throw an NPE when `PAssertStreaming` tries to access them.

I'm not 100% sure, but there may be the potential for a leak due to how we're constructing ExecutorServices, and that change would plug that leak (and regardless is probably a slightly superior invocation of feedbacks) (but I missed removing an export and thus build failures)
R: @davorbonaci

@tgroh Could you please have another look at the simplified test?

Btw, there's no longer a `GroupByKey` in the code, it's implicit in the `Count.perKey`. The test is not really testing `GroupByKey` but verifies that runners correctly hash/sort on the encoded value. Should I move this to a separate test file or leave it in `GroupByKeyTest`, what do you think @francesperry, since you suggested I move it to `GroupByKeyTest`?
Confirmed via `mvn verify` that the jars now have Guava shaded and repackaged properly.

Thanks for sharing this fix with us!

I had some inline comments.
Thanks for the comments. I updated the PR and will merge once Travis passes.

Can you rebase on top of master, to fix the diffs?

I think so long as you comment that `Count.perKey` expands into a transform that includes a GroupByKey, that's fine. Alternatively you could explicitly apply the `GroupByKey` and run a `Combine.groupedValues` on the `KV<K, Iter<V>>s` that result.
I rebased it on top of master.
Based on the dev list discussion, it looks like `DoFn` reuse might already be prevalent, so there's no downside here. Merging.
Thanks! Rebased and merged.

In the output of `mvn -Papache-release package`:

```
[INFO] --- maven-assembly-plugin:2.4.1:single (source-release-assembly) @ beam-parent ---
[INFO] Assemblies have been skipped per configuration of the skipAssembly parameter.
[INFO] 
```
R: @jbonofre @davorbonaci

I think we should more do a release-plugin configuration like this:

```
        <plugin>
          <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
          <artifactId>maven-release-plugin</artifactId>
          <version>2.5.3</version>
          <configuration>
            <useReleaseProfile>false</useReleaseProfile>
            <preparationGoals>clean install</preparationGoals>
            <goals>deploy</goals>
            <arguments>-Prelease</arguments>
            <autoVersionSubmodules>true</autoVersionSubmodules>
          </configuration>
        </plugin>
```

That would prevent to use the `apache-release` profile and keep our `release` profile.

Thanks for reviewing the test!

I think this is good to go one @orian also gives his OK.
LGTM
R: @davorbonaci

And what do we do for future binary distributions ?

Testing the output and content.
I'm checking if the artifactId is correct in the .m2/repository (and used for the deploy). It's good for target folder for sure, but not sure for the maven deploy. Checking.

I checked, in maven the source distribution is named:

beam-parent-0.2.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-source-release.zip

The content is correct.

My only concern is that the signatures are generated with this name, and we should upload apache-beam...zip on dist.apache.org (better than beam-parent-0.2.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-source-release.zip IMHO).

If we agree to do the rename manually of the source distribution and all related signature files, that's OK.

IMHO, it's better to have apache-beam...zip on dist.apache.org (as you can see for other projects on dist.apache.org/release like spark, karaf, etc).

As reminder, the purpose of the distributions module was:
1. use apache-beam as artifactId allowing us to directly have the correct filename in the maven coordinates used for the deploy (apache-beam...zip)
2. prepare the future to create binary distributions (using a specific assembly descriptor) like apache-beam-java-spark-bin...zip

Just checked with the rename of the zip file: the signature is still valid:

```
gpg --verify beam-parent-0.2.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-source-release.zip.asc foobar.zip 
gpg: Signature made Wed 08 Jun 2016 09:15:54 PM CEST using RSA key ID C8282E76
gpg: Good signature from "Jean-Baptiste OnofrÃ© <jbonofre@apache.org>"
gpg: WARNING: This key is not certified with a trusted signature!
gpg:          There is no indication that the signature belongs to the owner.
Primary key fingerprint: 1AA8 CF92 D409 A733 93D0  B736 BFF2 EE42 C828 2E76
```

So, I will update the release guide to explain that we have to upload from target folder (and not from the Maven local repo).

@swegner status of this? should it just be closed and abandoned?

I don't really understand the portability issue though.. I've used Beam API, and simply "skipped" the GlobalWindows and clone transformations applied by `CreateActual`, how is `AssertContains` more portable ?

And the reason actual is a SideInput as well is because the Beam SDK ends up calling `TwoSideInputAssert` that behaves this way..
Yes, I will close for now and revisit later.

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

The issue with using `PAssert` is that the the main input is in the Global Window and the side input is not, which means that lookups should fail (in fact, all `WindowFns` that are not `GlobalWindows` should fail if provided with the `GlobalWindow` as the main input window). Grouping the main input into a single pane and running the assertion on that pane ensures that the assertion is window-independent.

This mainly comes up if the precondition that the side input `WindowFn` is compatible with `GlobalWindows` (when no window is specified) is enforced.
Also, I have the same issue with local vs remote execution
Rebased and updated.

R: @kennknowles 

This isn't a particularly flexible way for the runner to handle exceptions, but should suffice until [BEAM-296](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-296) happens
What's the story with this PR? I'm working on getting Spark running the E2E tests in #345 and this was listed as a blocker there.
The main issue here is `Read.from` implementation.. I will try to get to that, but since Spark API is changing now, this might take a while..

OK. I can see why grouping all values into a single partition works. 
I guess `AssertContains` is preferred on how I used `PAssert#thatIterable` because it is portable, and I expect one (processing time) window..

Streaming support is definitely not in a good place for the Spark runner, so any (temporary) solution will do. Thanks!

As for the remote builds, I honestly can't come up with a good idea for that..

This is looking pretty good!

But I have some questions about the tests. Specifically, since we mostly test empty files it seems tough to validate that the decompressor does exactly what we expect.

I've added some suggestions for improvements.

Thanks,
